prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
- Sensitivity requirement:
We request a sensitivity of 0.06 mJy for continuum (df=7500 MHz), equivalent to a line sensitivity of 0.54 mJy (df=93.75 MHz), at band 6 (sensitivities here are 1 sigma).
Our goal of continuum observations is to improve the source counts in the flux range from 0.3 mJy to 2 mJy (5 sigma), as stated in the text. See section 2 along with Figure 1. Therefore we need a continuum sensitivity of 0.06 mJy (1 sigma).
For line observations, we will detect a line emitting source brighter than 2.7 mJy (5 sigma) for a velocity resolution of ~116 km/s, corresponding to a frequency resolution of df = 31.25 x 3 channels = 93.75 MHz. See section 3, science goal (6) for this requirement.
Note that the flux density of the brightest source known in the proposed field is about 3.0 mJy (at most) at 1.3 mm. Therefore, the required dynamic range is just 50, which must be not the issue for cy2 ALMA having >30 antennas.
- Imaging requirement:
Our goal is to obtain a contiguous rectangular 6' x 6' map. This is accomplished by 4 tiles of 3' x 3' box, and we need 85 pointings per tile (340 pointings in total) at the representative frequency (231 GHz). The spacing between adjacent pointings is set to 0.82 x FWHM of the 12-m antenna primary beam pattern. This is significantly larger than the Nyquist sampling rate (0.48), but we find that this is an acceptable compromise to reduce the number of pointing (ie., to reduce the overheads) without degrading the sensitivity uniformity over the mosaic; we find the expected sensitivity variation across the survey field is less than 10% in the proposed spacing, 0.82 (Morita & Holdaway 2005; Yamada et al. 2012). This level of uniformity is still sufficient because this is a point source detection program, not an imaging project of smoothly distributed extended emission.
The angular resolution we request is 0".9. Although we don't explicitly specify the array configuration, we are aware that this resolution will be achieved by C34-2 array. The maximum recoverable scale of C34-2, 11".2, is sufficient for the proposed maximum source size of 6", corresponding to a physical scale of ~50 kpc at z=2, which is sufficiently larger than the size of galaxies we want to observe.
- Correlator setup:
In order to maximize the continuum sensitivity, we emply the TDM mode, giving an effective frequency coverage of 7.5 GHz. The spectral resolutioin of TDM is 31.2 MHz or ~40 km/s at 1.3 mm, which is sufficient for any unexpected line detections from high-z galaxies. Note that we will smooth at least 3 channels to enhance the line sensitivity, as stated above.
Frequencies of 4 basebands are carefully determined to efficienly cover targetted redshift ranges to make volume-matched unbiased surveys of CO and H-alpha emitting galaxies.
Baseband 1 and 2 (LSB) are adjusted to cover a redshift range z = 2.173 - 2.227 (This gives a perfect match to the Subaru NB filter survey of H-alpha emitters at z = 2.191 +/- 0.020), and Baseband 3 and 4 (USB) are to z = 1.981 - 2.031, for observations of CO(6-5).
See section 2 for this requirement.
- Calibration:
We do not need any special calibration, including bandpass accuracy.
- Scheduling/time constraints:
We have no constraints.
- Data rate:
OT says the rate is 2.2 MB/s, which is comfortably below the limit.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose deep 6'x6'imaging of the SXDS-UDS-CANDELS field to a depth of 0.3 mJy (1.3 mm, 5 sigma) thereby ensuring a uniform census of galaxies with SFR > 50 Mo/yr up to z~10. This panoramic deep survey will be sufficiently sensitive to locate and study, for the first time, over a hundred faint sub-mJy galaxies thought to dominate the extragalactic background.
Our target field has unique ancillary data including (1) extensive surveys of emission-line galaxies selected with narrow-band filters, (2) ultra-deep (0.6 uJy, 1 sigma) JVLA C-band imaging and (3) confusion-limited deep SPIRE and AzTEC data. Our program is also designed to incorporate unbiased CO survey at several redshifts, including volume-matched CO(6-5) and Ha survey at z~2.2.
In conjunction with the rich dataset of ~20,000 WFC/IR-selected galaxies, we will determine the morphological nature of the sub-mJy population and clarify possible connections with line-emitting galaxies and faint radio-selected galaxies. Through the number counts, redshift distribution and clustering of this newly-found population, we will complete our understanding of the dust-obscured star formation history of the Universe.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
